questions.text: At what age does a child reach half of their adult height?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 20-24 months

Explanation:

Generally, a child's height at age 2 (20-24 months) years is half of their predicted adult height.

This milestone is often used as a reference point in paediatrics to estimate the future growth potential of the child.

 

  • Normal length at birth: 50cm.
  • In the first year, there is an increase of 25cm, so at 1 year, the height is 75cm.
  • In the second year, there is an increase of 10-15cm, so at 2 years, the height is 85-90cm.
  • There is a steady increase of 6cm/year till 12 years.

 

  • Height doubles by 4 years
  • Height triples by 12 years
  • Half of adult height in a normal child (80-85cm) is achieved by 2 years (18-24 months).

questions.text: A child with an IQ of 55 comes under:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Mild intellectual disability

Explanation:

Mild intellectual disability:

  • Intellectual disability: IQ < 70
  • IQ = (Mental age / Chronological age) x 100
  • Mild intellectual disability: IQ 51-70

questions.text: Following the delivery of a baby born to a mother with diabetes, the infant's blood glucose level was measured to be 60 mg/dl. What additional examination would you perform?
questions.solution:
Option D: Serum calcium

  • Infants born to diabetic mothers are at risk of developing hypoglycemia (low blood sugar) due to various factors, including high insulin levels in response to maternal hyperglycemia. Hypoglycemia in newborns can have significant consequences and requires careful management.
  • While a blood glucose level of 60 mg/dl indicates hypoglycemia in the infant, additional investigations are necessary to assess the overall metabolic status and potential complications. Among the options provided, serum calcium (option D) is the most relevant investigation to consider in this scenario.

Option A: Serum potassium

  • While alterations in electrolyte levels can occur in infants of diabetic mothers, serum potassium is not the most relevant investigation to perform immediately after observing a low blood glucose level. Hypokalemia (low potassium levels) can occur in various conditions, but in this specific case, assessing serum calcium is more important.

Option B: CBC (Complete Blood Count)

  • A complete blood count may provide information about the infant's overall blood cell counts, including red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. While it is a useful investigation in many clinical scenarios, it is not directly relevant to evaluating and managing hypoglycemia in this case.

Option C: Serum chloride

  • Serum chloride levels are not typically the primary concern when assessing an infant's metabolic status in the context of hypoglycemia. Therefore, it is not the most appropriate investigation to prioritize in this scenario.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with short stature. On evaluation, the bone age is found to be less than the chronological age. There are no dysmorphic features, and the child is otherwise healthy. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Constitutional delay of growth and puberty

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Constitutional delay of growth and puberty:

Explanation: Constitutional delay of growth and puberty (CDGP) is the most common cause of short stature in otherwise healthy children. It is characterized by:

  • Normal birth length and weight
  • Slowing of growth velocity during early childhood
  • Bone age delayed compared to chronological age
  • No dysmorphic features
  • Normal growth potential — eventual catch-up and normal adult height
  • Often a family history of “late bloomers”

Incorrect Options:

Familial short stature (Option B): Bone age is typically equal to chronological age; height is short but consistent with genetic potential.

Achondroplasia (Option C): Disproportionate short stature with rhizomelia (short limbs), frontal bossing, and characteristic facies.

Chondrodysplasia (Option D): A group of genetic disorders causing disproportionate short stature and skeletal abnormalities, usually evident early and with bone deformities.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with enuresis (bedwetting). The parents mention the child had a fall from bed once, but has no other significant medical history. There are no signs of urinary tract infection or neurological deficits. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Behavioral modification:

Explanation: In an 8-year-old with primary nocturnal enuresis (bedwetting since birth) and no evidence of urinary tract infection, neurological abnormality, or daytime symptoms, the first-line management is non-pharmacological behavioral measures. These include:

  • Limiting evening fluid intake
  • Scheduled voiding before bedtime
  • Positive reinforcement and reward systems
  • Enuresis alarms if behavioral methods alone are insufficient

Pharmacological therapy like desmopressin or oxybutynin is reserved for cases where behavioral measures fail, or when there is a need for rapid short-term control (e.g., sleepovers, camps).

Incorrect Options:

Start anticholinergic drugs (Option B): Used mainly for urge incontinence or overactive bladder, not first-line for primary nocturnal enuresis.

Prescribe oxybutynin (Option C): An anticholinergic; indicated for detrusor overactivity, not for initial management of simple nocturnal enuresis.

Start desmopressin therapy (Option D): Mimics ADH to reduce urine production at night; second-line after behavioral measures fail.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a 7-year-old child presenting with bedwetting complaints?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bed alarm:

  • A bedwetting alarm system consists of two parts:
    • Moisture sensor
    • Alarm
  • When it detects the moisture as the child passes urine, it wakes the child.
  • With time, the child gains the awareness to recognize and respond to the sensation of a full bladder, leading to control over bedwetting.
  • A bed alarm is most commonly recommended as the first line of treatment for bed wetting.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Imipramine: Imipramine is recommended when the bed alarm fails to show any result.

Option C - Desmopressin nasal spray: Desmopressin nasal spray is no longer licensed for bedwetting due to an increased incidence of side effects.

Option D - Fludrocortisone: Fludrocortisone is not used to treat bed-wetting.

Correct Option A - Phenylketonuria:

  • Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which leads to the accumulation of phenylalanine in the body.
  • If left untreated, elevated phenylalanine levels can cause severe intellectual disability and developmental delays.

Incorrect options:

Options B, C, and D do not cause intellectual disability.

Option B -Alkaptonuria:

  • Alkaptonuria is a metabolic disorder characterized by the accumulation of homogentisic acid.

Option C - Albinism:

  • Albinism is a genetic condition characterized by a lack of melanin production.

Option D - Von Gierke disease:

  • Von Gierke disease, also known as glycogen storage disease type I, is a metabolic disorder affecting glycogen metabolism.

questions.text: Craniopagus is defined as the fusion of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Head only:

  • Craniopagus involves the fusion of the heads of two individuals.
  • The craniopagus conjoined twins share the skull, meninges, and venous sinuses, and the brains are usually separate, although some cortical fusion can occur.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.
